items.content_html:
A team of researchers based in Norway and Japan might soon have you walking on desert sand, no matter how far from the dunes you live. This group of engineers has developed a method to transform it into a new construction material that's perfect for pavements ‚Äì and it can help reduce the need to destructively extract sand from rivers.

items.title: [Boing Boing] The 1817 table that reveals how words manipulate our thinking
items.content_html:
Back in 1817, philosopher Jeremy Bentham created a table showing how the same human impulse could be described in wildly different ways depending on your perspective. In one column, he'd write "gluttony" ‚Äì harsh and judgmental. In the next, "love of the pleasures of the social board" ‚Äì suddenly it sounds rather civilized, doesn't it? — Read the rest

The post The 1817 table that reveals how words manipulate our thinking appeared first on Boing Boing.

items.title: [New Atlas] [New Atlas] [New Atlas] [New Atlas] What if multiple sclerosis isn't just one disease?
items.content_html:
For decades, multiple sclerosis (MS) has been defined primarily by its symptoms, rather than its underlying biology. Now, a new study aims to challenge that approach, presenting evidence that MS may actually follow two distinct biological pathways. It‚Äôs a shift that could reshape how clinicians think about diagnoses, disease progression and treatment strategy.

Continue Reading

Category: Brain Health, Body and Mind

Tags: Multiple Sclerosis, Brain, Neurodegenerative conditions, Health, Disease, Diagnose

items.content_html: ‚ÄúAnthropause‚Äù is an amazing word and the latest book about it is an eye-opener.¬† Stan Cox‚Äôs¬†Anthropause: The Beauty of Degrowth (2026, Seven Stories Press), does what far too few degrowth books do ‚Äì it first focuses readers‚Äô attention to the positive experiences we could enjoy in a society less dedicated to producing unnecessary stuff.¬† It then details the destructiveness of overproduction.

items.title: [Resilience.org] [Resilience.org] [Resilience.org] [Resilience.org] [Resilience.org] [Resilience.org] [Resilience.org] A Primer For Paradigm Shift
items.content_html: There are near endless reasons to downsize to elevate our own value for what it means to be human. There are untold benefits to be gained when consumers become citizens. Paradigm shift starts at home and so do the benefits.

items.title: [Resilience.org] [Resilience.org] [Resilience.org] [Resilience.org] [Resilience.org] [Resilience.org] [Resilience.org] When Infrastructure Falls Apart, Living Systems Take Over
items.content_html: Resilience under prolonged crisis is not built through heroic acts or perfect systems. It grows from networks, from biological processes allowed to heal, from appropriate technologies, from communities that remain open rather than retreat inward.
